question.long: Does sugar substitute consumption increase the risk of developing cancer?

description: Results from studies evaluating the impact of sugar substitute consumption on the risk of developing cancer.

no_consensus.description: The literature has not yet reached a consensus on the effects of sugar substitutes on cancer

no.description: The literature suggests that sugar substitutes do not cause cancer

towards_no.description: The literature suggests that sugar substitutes probably don't cause cancer, but more research is needed

towards_yes.description: The literature suggests that sugar substitutes may cause cancer, but more research is needed

yes.description: The literature suggests that sugar substitutes cause cancer

no.description: The results of the paper show no significant effect of the sugar substitutes evaluated on the risk of developing cancer

no_unlike_literature.description: The results of the paper show no significant effect of the sugar substitutes evaluated on the risk of developing cancer, unlike what is reported in the literature

no_but_mixed_results.description: The results of the paper show no significant overall effect of the sugar substitutes evaluated on the risk of developing cancer, but there are mixed results on specific cases

maybe.description: The results of the paper suggest that the sugar substitutes evaluated might have an effect on the risk of developing cancer, but the evidence is not strong enough to conclude

yes_but_low_confidence.description: The results of the paper suggest that the sugar substitutes evaluated may increase the risk of developing cancer, but the evidence is not strong

yes_but_small_effect.description: The results of the paper suggest that the sugar substitutes evaluated may have a small effect on the risk of developing cancer

yes_unlike_literature.description: The results of the paper suggest that the sugar substitutes evaluated may increase the risk of developing cancer, unlike what is reported in the literature

yes.description: The results of the paper suggest that the sugar substitutes evaluated increase the risk of developing cancer

papers.title: Bladder Tumors in Rats Fed Cyclohexylamine or High Doses of a Mixture of Cyclamate and Saccharin
papers.quote: Papillary transitional cell tumors were found in the urinary bladders in 8 rats out of 80 that received 2600 milligrams per kilogram of body weight per day of a mixture of sodium cyclamate and sodium saccharin for up to 105 weeks

notes.title: Unrealistic doses
notes.description: The doses at which effects were observed are far beyond human-acceptable levels

papers.title: Bladder cancer mortality in England and Wales in relation to cigarette smoking and saccharin consumption
papers.quote: Examination of the trends in mortality from bladder cancer provides no evidence of any break in continuity that could be attributed to the use of saccharin since 1939

papers.title: Bladder cancer: smoking, beverages and artificial sweeteners.
papers.quote: Tea and coffee intake did not increase the risk of disease nor did prolonged use of artificial sweeteners

papers.title: Bladder cancer mortality in diabetics in relation to saccharin consumption and smoking habits.
papers.quote: In this study we have been unable to find evidence of an increased risk of bladder cancer in diabetics, some of whom must have consumed above average amounts of saccharin for more than 20 years

papers.title: Coffee Drinking and Cancer of the Lower Urinary Tract
papers.quote: Use of nondairy creamers, saccharin, or cyclamates was not associated with increased risk of disease

papers.title: Non-nutritive Sweeteners and Human Bladder Cancer: Preliminary Findings
papers.quote: The present findings suggest that ingestion of non-nutritive sweeteners, at least at the moderate dietary levels reported by our patient sample, is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners and human bladder cancer
papers.quote: We have demonstrated a positive association between use of artificial sweeteners and risk of bladder cancer in males. The effect has been demonstrated primarily for reported saccharin use, insufficient data being available to evaluate cyclamate use

papers.title: The epidemiology of bladder cancer: a second look
papers.quote: Users of artificial sweetners were not over-represented among the cases

papers.title: Saccharin, Cyclamate, and Human Bladder Cancer
papers.quote: It is concluded that neither saccharin nor cyclamate is likely to be carcinogenic in man, at least at the moderate dietary ingestion levels reported by the patient sample

papers.title: Artificial Sweetener Use and Bladder Cancer: A Case-Control Study
papers.quote: No association was found between use of artificial sweeteners or diet beverages and bladder cancer

papers.title: Artificial Sweeteners and Cancer of the Lower Urinary Tract
papers.quote: This study suggests that, as a group, users of artificial sweeteners have little or no excess risk of cancer of the lower urinary tract

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners and human bladder cancer
papers.quote: We conclude that past AS use has had a minimal effect, if any, on bladder cancer rates

papers.title: Incidence of brain tumors in rats fed aspartame
papers.quote: There was no significant difference in the incidence of brain tumors between control and test groups. It is concluded that neither APM nor DKP caused brain tumors in rats in this study

papers.title: The epidemiology of bladder cancer in West Yorkshire. A preliminary report on non-occupational aetiologies
papers.quote: In the present study saccharin was only investigated as a sugar substitute and a risk is apparent only amongst males who are non-smokers, a smaller and insignificant risk was demonstrated amongst non-smoking females. [...] The significance of these results is doubtful

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners and absence of bladder cancer risk in Copenhagen
papers.quote: This population-based case-control investigation provides further evidence that it is highly unlikely that the consumption of artificial sweeteners has contributed to current bladder cancer rates in man

papers.title: Evaluation of the dose response and in utero exposure to saccharin in the rat
papers.quote: A clear dose response for urinary bladder tumours was observed in the second-generation NaS-treated male rats

notes.title: Specific case
notes.description: The result only applies to male rats that were exposed in utero to a single sugar substitute (saccharin)

papers.title: A case-control study of factors affecting the development of renal cell cancer
papers.quote: No significant differences between cases and controls were found for either the amount or duration of artificial sweetener use or the lifetime consumption of saccharin

papers.title: Dietary factors and breast‚Äêcancer risk in Denmark
papers.quote: The risk of breast cancer was not associated with consumption of [...] artificial sweeteners

papers.title: Associations between Bladder Cancer Risk Factors and Tumor Stage and Grade at Diagnosis
papers.quote: Analysis of the total dataset revealed a modest association between heavy use of artificial sweeteners and risk of bladder cancer, but subsequent studies have not confirmed this association

papers.title: Increasing Brain Tumor Rates: Is There a Link to Aspartame?
papers.quote: Therefore, although our analysis does not establish definitive proof of a causal link between aspartame and the recent increase in incidence and shift in malignancy of brain tumors that occurred in the United States several years after aspartame was introduced, it does indicate the need for a reassessment of the carcinogenic potential of this agent which is currently being ingested widely throughout many parts of the world

papers.title: Aspartame Consumption in Relation to Childhood Brain Tumor Risk: Results From a Case-Control Study
papers.quote: Case children were no more likely than control children to consume foods containing aspartame, either from all sources of aspartame combined or from diet drinks. There was no suggestion of a dose-response relation based on age at first consumption, number of years of consumption, or frequency of consumption

papers.title: Long-Term Toxicity and Carcinogenicity Study of Cyclamate in Nonhuman Primates
papers.quote: The overall conclusion is that the testicular abnormalities and the sporadic cases of different malignancies found after more than 20 years of dosing do not provide clear evidence of a toxic or carcinogenic effect of sodium cyclamate in monkeys

papers.title: Aspartame: Review of Safety
papers.quote: The conclusion of this up-to-date review is in agreement with that of international regulatory agencies and expert committees: the weight of scientific evidence is clear that aspartame is safe for its intended use

papers.title: The comet assay with 8 mouse organs: results with 39 currently used food additives
papers.quote: Four sweeteners (sodium cyclamate, saccharin, sodium saccharin, and sucralose) also induced DNA damage in gastrointestinal organs

notes.title: Unrealistic doses
notes.description: The doses at which effects were observed are far beyond human-acceptable levels

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners‚Äîdo they bear a carcinogenic risk?
papers.quote: As many artificial sweeteners are combined in today‚Äôs products, the carcinogenic risk of a single substance is difficult to assess. However, according to the current literature, the possible risk of artificial sweeteners to induce cancer seems to be negligible

papers.title: First Experimental Demonstration of the Multipotential Carcinogenic Effects of Aspartame Administered in the Feed to Sprague-Dawley Rats
papers.quote: The results of this mega-experiment indicate that APM is a multipotential carcinogenic agent, even at a daily dose of 20 mg/kg body weight, much less than the current acceptable daily intake

notes.title: Controversial institute
notes.description: The Ramazzini Institute has a long history of controversial studies (generally claiming that things cause cancer) criticized for methodological and design flaws like data transparency issues, lack of randomization, and more. The institute has also been criticized for its practice of issuing high‚Äëvisibility press releases before peer‚Äëreview and for its links with biased NGOs and political groups

notes.title: No dose-response relationship
notes.description: Low and inconsistent dose-response relationship despite huge differences in dose between groups (several orders of magnitude)

notes.title: Non-standard design
notes.description: Data transparency issues, high‚Äëdensity housing, use of pathogen‚Äëcarrier animals and full‚Äëlifespan design

papers.title: Sugar-Sweetened Soft Drink Consumption and Risk of Pancreatic Cancer in Two Prospective Cohorts
papers.quote: We similarly examined the risk of pancreatic cancer according to intake of diet soft drinks but failed to observe a significant relation between diet soft drink intake and pancreatic cancer risk

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners and cancer risk in a network of case‚Äìcontrol studies
papers.quote: This study provides no evidence that saccharin or other sweeteners (mainly aspartame) increase the risk of cancer at several common sites in humans

papers.title: Consumption of Aspartame-Containing Beverages and Incidence of Hematopoietic and Brain Malignancies
papers.quote: Our findings do not support the hypothesis that aspartame increases hematopoietic or brain cancer risk

papers.title: Aspartame: A Safety Evaluation Based on Current Use Levels, Regulations, and Toxicological and Epidemiological Studies
papers.quote: The studies provide no evidence to support an association between aspartame and cancer in any tissue. The weight of existing evidence is that aspartame is safe at current levels of consumption as a nonnutritive sweetener

papers.title: Life-Span Exposure to Low Doses of Aspartame Beginning during Prenatal Life Increases Cancer Effects in Rats
papers.quote: The results of this carcinogenicity bioassay confirm and reinforce the first experimental demonstration of APM‚Äôs multipotential carcinogenicity at a dose level close to the acceptable daily intake for humans

notes.title: Controversial institute
notes.description: The Ramazzini Institute has a long history of controversial studies (generally claiming that things cause cancer) criticized for methodological and design flaws like data transparency issues, lack of randomization, and more. The institute has also been criticized for its practice of issuing high‚Äëvisibility press releases before peer‚Äëreview and for its links with biased NGOs and political groups

notes.title: Non-standard design
notes.description: Data transparency issues, high‚Äëdensity housing, use of pathogen‚Äëcarrier animals and full‚Äëlifespan design

papers.title: Artificial sweetener consumption and urinary tract tumors in Cordoba, Argentina
papers.quote: Regular use of AS for 10 years or more was positively associated with UTT

papers.title: Artificial Sweeteners and the Risk of Gastric, Pancreatic, and Endometrial Cancers in Italy
papers.quote: The present study adds further evidence on the absence of an adverse effect of low-calorie sweetener (including aspartame) consumption on the risk of common neoplams in the Italian population

papers.title: Mycoplasma pulmonis and Lymphoma in Bioassays in Rats
papers.quote: We suggest that a plausible alternative explanation for the reported results of these bioassays is that the studies were confounded by M. pulmonis disease and that lesions of the disease were interpreted as lymphoma

papers.title: Sweets, sweetened beverages, and risk of pancreatic cancer in a large population-based case‚Äìcontrol study
papers.quote: Low-calorie soft drinks were associated with increased risk among men only

papers.title: Aspartame administered in feed, beginning prenatally through life span, induces cancers of the liver and lung in male Swiss mice
papers.quote: The results of the present study confirm that APM is a carcinogenic agent in multiple sites in rodents, and that this effect is induced in two species, rats (males and females) and mice (males). No carcinogenic effects were observed in female mice

notes.title: Controversial institute
notes.description: The Ramazzini Institute has a long history of controversial studies (generally claiming that things cause cancer) criticized for methodological and design flaws like data transparency issues, lack of randomization, and more. The institute has also been criticized for its practice of issuing high‚Äëvisibility press releases before peer‚Äëreview and for its links with biased NGOs and political groups

notes.title: Non-standard design
notes.description: Data transparency issues, high‚Äëdensity housing, use of pathogen‚Äëcarrier animals and full‚Äëlifespan design

papers.title: Consumption of artificial sweetener‚Äì and sugar-containing soda and risk of lymphoma and leukemia in men and women
papers.quote: Although our findings preserve the possibility of a detrimental effect of a constituent of diet soda, such as aspartame, on select cancers, the inconsistent sex effects and occurrence of an apparent cancer risk in individuals who consume regular soda do not permit the ruling out of chance as an explanation

notes.title: Inconsistent results
notes.description: Depending on the case, there was an association for only one gender or for only both genders together

papers.title: Aspartame, low-calorie sweeteners and disease: Regulatory safety and epidemiological issues
papers.quote: With reference to epidemiologic data, evidence on low-calorie sweeteners ‚Äì and specifically aspartame ‚Äì does not support the existence of a consistent association with hematopoietic neoplasms, brain cancer, digestive sites, breast, prostate and several other neoplasms

papers.title: Scientific Opinion on the re‚Äêevaluation of aspartame (E 951) as a food additive
papers.quote: Overall, the Panel considered that the results of these epidemiological studies do not suggest an increased risk associated with aspartame consumption for the types of cancer examined

papers.title: Artificially and Sugar-Sweetened Carbonated Beverage Consumption Is Not Associated with Risk of Lymphoid Neoplasms in Older Men and Women
papers.quote: Overall, results of this study suggest that moderate consumption levels of artificially and sugar-sweetened carbonated beverages are unlikely to increase the risk of NHL in older men and women

papers.title: Consumption of soft drinks and juices and risk of liver and biliary tract cancers in a European cohort
papers.quote: In sub-group analyses available for 91% of the cohort artificially sweetened soft drinks increased HCC risk by 6% per 1 serving increment

papers.title: Sweetened carbonated beverage consumption and cancer risk
papers.quote: The meta-analyses showed no link with the consumption of sweetened, carbonated beverages and the risk of cancer overall or individual types of cancer

papers.title: The effect of five artificial sweeteners on Caco-2, HT-29 and HEK-293 cells
papers.quote: Sucralose and sodium saccharin seemed to elicit the greatest degree of DNA fragmentation of all the sweeteners tested in all the cell lines used

papers.title: The Role of Dietary and Lifestyle Factors in the Development of Colorectal Cancer: Case Control Study in Minia, Egypt
papers.quote: The most significant dietary and lifestyle CRC risk factors were higher consumption of red meat, preserved food, artificial sweeteners, fast foods, soft drinks, spicy foods, processed meat, and smoking

notes.title: Questionable results
notes.description: The reported effect is very imprecise (odds ratio between 2.7 and 159.7) and extremely large (twice that of smoking and 20 times that of alcohol) which clearly stands out from the rest of the literature

papers.title: Review of the nutritional benefits and risks related to intense sweeteners
papers.quote: On the whole, the epidemiological studies do not show any effects of IS consumption on cancer risk

papers.title: Systematic review of the relationship between artificial sweetener consumption and cancer in humans: analysis of 599,741 participants
papers.quote: The statistical value of this review is limited by the heterogeneity and observational designs of the included studies. Although there is limited evidence to suggest that heavy consumption may increase the risk of certain cancers, overall the data presented are inconclusive as to any relationship between artificial sweeteners and cancer

papers.title: Sucralose Non-Carcinogenicity: A Review of the Scientific and Regulatory Rationale
papers.quote: In summary, sucralose does not demonstrate carcinogenic activity even when exposure levels are several orders of magnitude greater than the range of anticipated daily ingestion levels

papers.title: Sweet-beverage consumption and risk of pancreatic cancer in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)
papers.quote: In conclusion, in this large prospective cohort study, no soft-drink category was associated with pancreatic cancer

papers.title: Health outcomes of non-nutritive sweeteners: analysis of the research landscape
papers.quote: In healthy subjects appetite and short term food intake, risk of cancer, risk of diabetes, risk of dental caries are the most investigated health outcomes, all of them without any conclusive evidence

papers.title: Consumption of sugar-sweetened and artificially sweetened soft drinks and risk of obesity-related cancers
papers.quote: For artificially sweetened soft drinks, the HR for obesity-related cancers was not associated with consumption

papers.title: Systematic review and evaluation of aspartame carcinogenicity bioassays using quality criteria
papers.quote: As the Klimisch Code 2 studies demonstrated a lack of carcinogenic potential, and as aspartame is hydrolyzed to common components and lacks genotoxic activity, a conclusion that aspartame is not carcinogenic is supported

papers.title: 5Association between intake of non-sugar sweeteners and health outcomes: systematic review and meta-analyses of randomised and non-randomised controlled trials and observational studies
papers.quote: Most health outcomes did not seem to have differences between the NSS exposed and unexposed groups

papers.title: Consumption of sugar‚Äêsweetened and artificially sweetened soft drinks and risk of cancers not related to obesity
papers.quote: The positive association we observed in the present study between frequency of consumption of artificially-sweetened soft drinks and cancer unrelated to obesity was not expected and could be due to unmeasured confounding or to chance

papers.title: Lack of potential carcinogenicity for aspartame ‚Äì Systematic evaluation and integration of mechanistic data into the totality of the evidence
papers.quote: The consistency in lack of carcinogenic findings in experimental animal and human studies collectively demonstrate that aspartame consumption is unlikely to be carcinogenic to humans

papers.title: Sugary drink consumption and risk of cancer: results from NutriNet-Sant√© prospective cohort
papers.quote: The consumption of artificially sweetened beverages was not associated with the risk of cancer

papers.title: High Concentrations of Aspartame Induce Pro-Angiogenic Effects in Ovo and Cytotoxic Effects in HT-29 Human Colorectal Carcinoma Cells
papers.quote: The concentrations that proved to be cytotoxic in vitro exerted a pro-angiogenic effect in ovo and presented a weak irritant potential at vascular level. These data might represent a background for further studies aiming to elucidate aspartame‚Äôs mechanism of action in tumor cells

papers.title: Identification of aspartame-induced haematopoietic and lymphoid tumours in rats after lifetime treatment
papers.quote: After the HLT cases re-evaluation, the results obtained are consistent with those reported in the previous RI publication and reinforce the hypothesis that APM has a leukaemogenic and lymphomatogenic effect

notes.title: Controversial institute
notes.description: The Ramazzini Institute has a long history of controversial studies (generally claiming that things cause cancer) criticized for methodological and design flaws like data transparency issues, lack of randomization, and more. The institute has also been criticized for its practice of issuing high‚Äëvisibility press releases before peer‚Äëreview and for its links with biased NGOs and political groups

notes.title: Non-independent review
notes.description: The authors of the review are affiliated with the same institute that produced the reviewed paper

papers.title: Aspartame and cancer ‚Äì new evidence for causation
papers.quote: These new findings confirm that aspartame is a chemical carcinogen in rodents

notes.title: Controversial institute
notes.description: The Ramazzini Institute has a long history of controversial studies (generally claiming that things cause cancer) criticized for methodological and design flaws like data transparency issues, lack of randomization, and more. The institute has also been criticized for its practice of issuing high‚Äëvisibility press releases before peer‚Äëreview and for its links with biased NGOs and political groups

notes.title: Non-independent review
notes.description: The authors of the review are affiliated with the same institute that produced the reviewed papers

papers.title: Association of soft drink and 100% fruit juice consumption with all-cause mortality, cardiovascular diseases mortality, and cancer mortality: A systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies
papers.quote: The association of SSBs and ASBs with cancer mortality was not significant, with a very low certainty of evidence

papers.title: Consumption of Sweet Beverages and Cancer Risk. A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies
papers.quote: Current evidence indicates that higher incidence of some cancers is related to a high consumption of SSBs. However, the evidence is limited to make recommendations regarding ASBs and FJs. This subject requires further investigation

papers.title: Intake of artificial sweeteners among adults is associated with reduced odds of gastrointestinal luminal cancers: a meta-analysis of cohort and case-control studies
papers.quote: Overall, these data, which represent over 1 million people globally, are congruent with the majority of contemporary epidemiological data demonstrating no association between AS and increased risk of cancer

papers.title: Soft Drink and Juice Consumption and Renal Cell Carcinoma Incidence and Mortality in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition
papers.quote: There was no higher risk of incident RCC associated with consumption of juices, total soft drinks, sugar-sweetened soft drinks, or artificially sweetened soft drinks

papers.title: Sugar-Sweetened Beverages, Artificially Sweetened Beverages, and Breast Cancer Risk: Results From 2 Prospective US Cohorts
papers.quote: Our findings also suggest no substantial increase in the risk of breast cancer with consumption of ASBs

papers.title: The relationship between the use of artificial sweeteners and cancer: A meta‚Äêanalysis of case‚Äìcontrol studies
papers.quote: Our findings indicated that the consumption of artificial sweeteners was not associated with an increase in cancer when all types of cancers are analyzed comprehensively. Interestingly, the use of artificial sweeteners is inversely related to urinary system cancer risk when analyzing women individually

papers.title: Artificial sweeteners and cancer risk: Results from the NutriNet-Sant√© population-based cohort study
papers.quote: This large-scale population-based cohort study suggests associations between artificial sweeteners, especially aspartame and acesulfame-K, and cancer risk, more specifically breast and obesity-related cancers

notes.title: No dose-response relationship
notes.description: Risk of cancer was often similar or even higher in the lower consumer group than the higher consumer group

papers.title: Association of Artificially Sweetened Beverage Consumption and Urinary Tract Cancers in the Women‚Äôs Health Initiative Observational Study
papers.quote: In this study of postmenopausal women in the USA, higher consumption of ASBs was associated with a higher risk of incident kidney cancer, but not with the risk of incident bladder cancer

papers.title: Can Artificial Sweeteners Increase the Risk of Cancer Incidence and Mortality: Evidence from Prospective Studies
papers.quote: The results of our research demonstrated that artificial sweeteners‚Äô intake seemed not to increase the risk of overall cancer incidence and mortality. However, in Europe, the consumption of artificial sweeteners could increase cancer incidence

papers.title: Is the Use of Artificial Sweeteners Beneficial for Patients with Diabetes Mellitus? The Advantages and Disadvantages of Artificial Sweeteners
papers.quote: Only European data showed an association with cancer incidence, as opposed to the United States or Oceania. [...] In the NutriNet-Sante population-based cohort study, artificial sweeteners were also associated with increased cancer risk. [...] This finding might be due to the relationship between obesity and artificial sweeteners

papers.title: Sweetened beverage consumption and risk of liver cancer by diabetes status: A pooled analysis
papers.quote: Among persons with diabetes, AS soda consumption was linked to liver cancer

papers.title: Artificially Sweetened Beverages and Health Outcomes: An Umbrella Review
papers.quote: Weak observational evidence was observed for other health outcomes: cancer risk at several sites (colorectal, pancreatic, and gastrointestinal), cancer mortality, chronic kidney disease, or cardiovascular mortality

papers.title: Association between Artificial Sweetener-Aspartame Consumption and Colorectal Cancer Risk: Evidence-Based Strategies
papers.quote: Moreover, low, medium, and high exposures were not associated with an increased risk of mortality due to CRC. The results of our meta-analysis showed that a low intake of ASs may be associated with a lower risk of CRC

papers.title: Association between Consumption of Artificial Sweeteners and Breast Cancer Risk: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies
papers.quote: This study confirmed that there was no relationship between the exposure of artificial sweeteners and the incidence of BC

papers.title: Association between consumption of sweeteners and endometrial cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis of observational studies
papers.quote: According to statistical findings, there was no difference in the incidence of EC between population exposed to nonnutritional sweeteners and those not exposed to non-nutritional sweeteners

papers.title: Carcinogenicity of aspartame, methyleugenol, and isoeugenol
papers.quote: Aspartame was classified as "possibly carcinogenic to humans" (Group 2B) based on "limited" evidence for cancer in humans

notes.title: Controversial references
notes.description: Most of the studies referenced as evidence of an effect have faced significant criticism regarding their methods and interpretation

papers.title: Consumption of aspartame and other artificial sweeteners and risk of cancer in the Spanish multicase‚Äêcontrol study (MCC‚ÄêSpain)
papers.quote: We did not find associations between use of AS and cancer, but found associations between high consumption of aspartame and other AS and different cancer types among participants with diabetes

papers.title: Is there a promoting role for artificial sweeteners in the evolution of bladder cancer? A meta-analysis of current literature
papers.quote: According to our results, the carcinogenic risk of artificial sweeteners is not proven. Saccharin should not be kept as a promoter in urothelial malignant transformation

papers.title: Non-sugar sweeteners and cancer: Toxicological and epidemiological evidence
papers.quote: Based on the review of both the experimental data on genotoxicity or carcinogenicity of the specific NSS evaluated, and the epidemiological studies it can be concluded that there is no evidence of cancer risk associated to NSS consumption

papers.title: Sugar-Sweetened and Artificially Sweetened Beverages and Risk of Liver Cancer and Chronic Liver Disease Mortality
papers.quote: Compared with intake of 3 or fewer artificially sweetened beverages per month, individuals who consumed 1 or more artificially sweetened beverages per day did not have significantly increased incidence of liver cancer or chronic liver disease mortality

papers.title: Sweeteners and the Gut Microbiome: Effects on Gastrointestinal Cancers
papers.quote: Here, and in most of the reported articles, it has been shown that these natural and synthetic sweeteners lack genotoxicity and carcinogenicity and are safe when consumed in moderation

papers.title: The Impact of Artificial Sweeteners on Human Health and Cancer Association: A Comprehensive Clinical Review
papers.quote: Although multiple studies associate ASs with increased cancer risk, the majority of recent research data, including systematic reviews and meta-analyses, show no link between the use of ASs and cancer risk

papers.title: Artificially sweetened beverages consumption and risk of obesity-related cancers: a wide-angled Mendelian randomization study
papers.quote: Genetically predicted ASB consumption was positively associated with the risk of colorectal cancer and breast cancer

papers.title: Chronic Use of Artificial Sweeteners: Pros and Cons
papers.quote: The relationship between the consumption of artificial sweeteners and the occurrence of cancer according to meta-analyses is inconsistent

papers.title: Consumption of aspartame and risk of breast cancer in the Nurses‚Äô Health Studies
papers.quote: Overall, there was no association between aspartame consumption and invasive breast cancer risk. [...] In these cohorts, aspartame consumption did not increase breast cancer risk

papers.title: Research Progress on the Relationship Between Artificial Sweeteners and Breast Cancer
papers.quote: The relationship between artificial sweeteners and breast cancer remains unclear, and existing research results are contradictory

papers.title: An integrative analysis reveals cancer risk associated with artificial sweeteners
papers.quote: This study integrated data mining, machine learning, network toxicology, molecular docking, molecular dynamics simulations, and clinical sample analysis to demonstrate that AS increases the risk of kidney cancer, lowgrade glioma, breast cancer, and prostate cancer through multiple targets and signaling pathways

papers.title: Artificial Sweeteners: Benefits, Risks and Controversy
papers.quote: The possible risk of carcinogenesis reported with AS use is seen only in much higher exposure than the ADI level

papers.title: Aspartame and Human Health: A Mini-Review of Carcinogenic and Systemic Effects
papers.quote: In summary, this mini-review has examined the potential link between aspartame and carcinogenesis. While some studies suggest a possible association, the overall body of evidence remains inconclusive
